nodes.text: How do the allocation of students to colleges and college characteristics affect income segregation across colleges and intergenerational income mobility in the United States?

Method: Construct near-complete, deidentified administrative dataset linking federal tax records, Department of Education records, College Board and ACT data to obtain parents' household incomes, students' college attendance, SAT/ACT scores, and students' earnings in early 30s for cohorts born 1980–1991 (focus 1980–82).

Method: Define parent income as five-year average household pretax income when child aged 15–19; define child earnings as individual earnings in 2014 (ages 32–34); assign each student to the college they attended most between ages 19–22; use college tiers (Barron's) and public/private two- vs four-year splits.

Method: Estimate three parameter sets: parental income distributions by college; students' earnings outcomes conditional on parent income by college; and portion of variation in earnings attributable to colleges' causal effects; then simulate counterfactual reallocations of students across colleges using observed SAT/ACT, race, and geography.

Evidence: Degree of parental income segregation across colleges is very high: Ivy-Plus colleges enroll 14.5% from top 1% vs 3.8% from bottom quintile; children from top 1% are 77 times more likely to attend Ivy-Plus than bottom-quintile children; community colleges have 14.6% bottom-quintile and 0.5% top 1%.

Evidence: Segregation across colleges is comparable to segregation across childhood neighborhoods (ZIP-code level): exposure indices for peers by parental income are similar for college peers and childhood neighborhood peers when pooling all children.

Evidence: Within a given college, the relationship between child earnings rank and parent income rank is much weaker than nationally: national rank-rank slope ~0.29; controlling for college fixed effects reduces slope to ~0.10 among college-goers and to ~0.065 at elite colleges.

Evidence: Colleges differ in mean earnings outcomes and mobility rates; many mid-tier public colleges (e.g., CUNY, Cal State campuses, SUNY Stony Brook) combine high shares of low-income students with relatively high upward mobility rates, while Ivy-Plus colleges have high upper-tail (top 1%) mobility but low shares of low-income students.

Evidence on test scores: SAT/ACT scores rise with parental income; high-scoring (e.g., 1300+) students are disproportionately from high-income families—only ~3.7% of 1300+ scorers come from bottom quintile—so few low-income students have sufficiently high scores for elite colleges.

Claim: Most of the national intergenerational earnings gap arises from between-college differences (who attends which college) rather than within-college gaps; conditional on college, parent-income gradient in outcomes is much smaller.

Claim: High mobility (bottom-to-top quintile) colleges are heterogeneous in institutional characteristics (many are mid-tier public) while upper-tail mobility (bottom to top 1%) is concentrated in highly selective, high-expenditure private colleges with large endowments.

Assumption: In baseline simulations assume 80% of observational differences in students' earnings across colleges (conditional on test scores, race, and parental income) are causal (college value-added) and 20% due to selection; also assume colleges' causal effects are unchanged under reallocations.

Result (income-neutral counterfactual): Allocating students to colleges randomly conditional on SAT/ACT, race, and state (holding racial and geographic composition and college sizes fixed) would substantially reduce segregation overall (about 64% of possible reduction toward random allocation among current college-goers) and would reduce the gap in probability of reaching top earnings quintile between top- and bottom-parent quintiles by about 15% (assuming 80% causal share).

Result (need-affirmative counterfactual): Giving low- and middle-income students a sliding-scale admissions preference equivalent to boosting their SAT by ~160 points for bottom quintile (and proportionally less for higher quintiles) would essentially equalize parental income distributions across college tiers and could reduce intergenerational income persistence among college students by about 25% (assuming 80% causal share).

Limitation / Counterevidence: Simulated effects on mobility are sensitive to the assumed causal share; effects mechanically fall toward zero if differences across colleges are pure selection (0% causal) and rise if causal share is higher; analyses ignore potential equilibrium effects and possible changes in college value-added when student composition changes.

Conclusion: Changing how students are allocated to colleges—by reducing application, admission, and matriculation gaps conditional on academic credentials or by implementing need-affirmative preferences—could substantially reduce income segregation across colleges and increase intergenerational mobility even without changing colleges' educational programs, though results depend on causal-effect assumptions.
